results.title: Lost
results.creator_credit: Jo Kennedy, Clare Sawyer and Ros Walker
results.brief_description: Three small children have been wandering a city beach. What begins as a seemingly routine case for detectives in Missing Persons becomes a puzzle. Twenty-four hours later no one has reported them missing and the police start to worry. Why can’t they locate their parents and why won’t the children speak?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jo Kennedy, Clare Sawyer and Ros Walker

results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.

results.title: In My Room
results.brief_description: Being a teenager is hell. But in your private space, your bedroom, you can be yourself. In My Room enters the bedrooms of three teenagers: Kristy, a 17 year old who lives with her mum in a St. Kilda flat; Will, a 16 year old, boarding in a room with three other boys at Melbourne Grammar; and Jyka, a 14 year old Koorie who lives with his family in Broadmeadows. This film tells the story of their private places, filled with possessions that represent their past and future and the changing perspectives and passions affecting their lives.

results.title: Icon
results.brief_description: A comedy about the gender of god and the real wishes of the Virgin Mary. Hugely successful, this one minute short has screened at festivals throughout Australia and Europe, and at the United Women’s Conference in Beijing.
results.description: A comedy about the gender of god and the real wishes of the Virgin Mary. Hugely successful, this one minute short has screened at festivals throughout Australia and Europe, and at the United Women’s Conference in Beijing.

results.title: Harry's War ( Crossing Tracks )
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, Jill Bilcock and John Foss
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Fly Peewee, Fly!
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boy, Robbie is in the midst of the conflict between his father and his grandmother. Robbie’s grandmother is white and wants to give Robbie every advantage, while Robbie’s aboriginal father is searching for his own identity and place. A warm story about fragile but meaningful family relationships.

results.title: First love
results.brief_description: First Love is a story about 2 teenagers, discovering “first love” and each others bodies. A secret meeting in a school workshop leads to an intimate encounter and the exchange of rings. A tale of discovery, exploration, facination and body piercing that has delighted film festival audiences in Australia, Sweden, Spain and the United States.

results.title: Evictions
results.creator_credit: Richard Lowenstein, Wendy Lowenstein, Lyn Nicolson, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Documentary/drama on police-enforced evictions in Melbourne during the 1930’s depression and the tactics the organised unemployed used at the time to combat the situation. Based on the memories of Noel Counihan and Tom Hills and adapted from the book ‘Weevils in the flour’ by Wendy Lowenstein, the film combines interviews with period reconstruction. Erwin Rado Award for Best Australian Short Fiction, Melbourne Film Festival, 1980.
